content.title: Chronic Pancreatitis
content.summary: Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disorder characterized by irreversible destruction of pancreatic parenchyma leading to exocrine and endocrine insufficiency. The most common cause is chronic alcohol use. Management focuses on pain control, pancreatic enzyme replacement, and addressing complications.
key_points: Progressive fibrosis with loss of exocrine (enzymes) and endocrine (insulin) function
Alcohol (70-80%) and smoking are major risk factors
Classic triad: Chronic epigastric pain, steatorrhea, diabetes mellitus
Diagnosis: CT showing calcifications; MRCP/EUS for early disease
Treatment: Pain management, enzyme replacement (PERT), diabetes control
Complications: Pseudocyst, CBD obstruction, splenic vein thrombosis, pancreatic cancer
content.statement: Chronic pancreatitis causes progressive pancreatic damage with irreversible loss of exocrine and endocrine function, requiring multidisciplinary management of pain, malabsorption, and diabetes while monitoring for complications.

explanation.intuition: Think of chronic pancreatitis as the pancreas slowly scarring itself to death from repeated injury. Unlike acute pancreatitis where the pancreas can heal, chronic pancreatitis is like a house that has been damaged so many times it's now permanently structurally unsound. The factories inside (enzyme-producing and insulin-producing cells) are destroyed and replaced by scar tissue.
explanation.key_insight: The 'burnt-out' phase is important to recognize: paradoxically, as the pancreas is destroyed, PAIN may improve because the inflamed tissue is replaced by non-painful scar tissue. However, malabsorption and diabetes worsen. Don't assume improved pain means disease is better - it may mean the pancreas is now non-functional.
explanation.technical_details: Pathogenesis involves repeated episodes of necrosis-fibrosis (necrosis-fibrosis hypothesis) or oxidative stress from alcohol/metabolites. Calcifications (intraductal stones) are pathognomonic on CT. EUS shows parenchymal (lobularity, stranding, cysts, hyperechoic foci) and ductal (irregularity, dilation, stones) changes.

definitions_glossary.chronic_pancreatitis: Progressive inflammatory disorder with irreversible pancreatic damage
definitions_glossary.exocrine_insufficiency: Inadequate enzyme secretion causing malabsorption and steatorrhea
definitions_glossary.endocrine_insufficiency: Type 3c diabetes mellitus from islet cell destruction
definitions_glossary.steatorrhea: Fatty, foul-smelling, floating stools from fat malabsorption
definitions_glossary.pancreatic_calcifications: Intraductal calcium deposits; pathognomonic on imaging
definitions_glossary.pancreatic_duct_dilation: Main duct >3mm; chain-of-lakes pattern suggests stricture alternating with dilation
definitions_glossary.PERT: Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy - lipase supplements with meals
definitions_glossary.pseudocyst: Encapsulated fluid collection with defined wall; complication of pancreatitis
definitions_glossary.CBD_obstruction: Common bile duct compression by fibrotic pancreatic head
definitions_glossary.splenic_vein_thrombosis: May cause left-sided portal hypertension with gastric varices
definitions_glossary.Rosemont_criteria: EUS-based diagnostic criteria for chronic pancreatitis

pathophysiology.mechanism: Repeated pancreatic injury leads to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, atrophy, calcification, and ductal strictures with progressive loss of parenchyma

alcohol.mechanism: Oxidative stress, toxic metabolites, protein plugs

etiologies.smoking: Independent risk factor; synergistic with alcohol

disease_progression.advanced: Calcifications, steatorrhea, diabetes ('burnt-out' with less pain)

clinical_presentation: Chronic or recurrent epigastric pain radiating to back

imaging.CT: Calcifications (most specific), ductal dilation, parenchymal atrophy
imaging.MRCP: Ductal abnormalities (dilation, strictures, side branch ectasia)
imaging.EUS: Most sensitive for early disease; Rosemont criteria (parenchymal and ductal features)

differential_diagnosis: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma (mass lesion, weight loss, painless jaundice)
Recurrent acute pancreatitis (episodes with recovery between)
Peptic ulcer disease (H. pylori, NSAID history)

pain_management.approach: Stepwise: lifestyle modification → analgesics → pancreatic enzymes → interventions
pain_management.medications: Non-opioids first; opioids for refractory pain
pain_management.pancreatic_enzymes: May reduce pain by feedback inhibition of pancreatic secretion
pain_management.interventional: ERCP for strictures/stones; EUS-guided celiac plexus block
pain_management.surgical: Total pancreatectomy with islet autotransplantation (TPIAT) for refractory pain

exocrine_insufficiency.PERT: Lipase 40,000-50,000 units with meals, 25,000 with snacks
exocrine_insufficiency.PPI: Add if response inadequate (protects enzymes from acid)

endocrine_insufficiency.type_3c_diabetes: Insulin therapy often required; 'brittle' due to glucagon deficiency
endocrine_insufficiency.monitoring: HbA1c, hypoglycemia risk higher than type 1/2 DM

complications.pseudocyst: Drain if symptomatic or enlarging; EUS-guided or surgical
complications.biliary_obstruction: ERCP with stent or surgical bypass
complications.splenic_vein_thrombosis: Monitor for gastric varices; splenectomy if bleeding

definition.@value: A progressive inflammatory disorder of the pancreas characterized by irreversible morphologic changes, chronic pain, and progressive loss of exocrine and endocrine function

scopeNote.@value: Covers etiology, diagnosis, and management of chronic pancreatitis and its complications

learning_objectives: Identify major etiologies of chronic pancreatitis including alcohol and genetic causes
Describe the clinical triad of pain, steatorrhea, and diabetes
Select appropriate imaging based on disease stage
Design management strategy for pain and malabsorption
Recognize and manage complications of chronic pancreatitis
clinical_pearls: Steatorrhea requires >90% loss of pancreatic function - occurs late
Calcifications on CT are PATHOGNOMONIC for chronic pancreatitis
EUS is most sensitive for early/minimal change disease
Type 3c diabetes has high hypoglycemia risk due to glucagon deficiency
Chronic pancreatitis increases pancreatic cancer risk 10-20x
common_misconceptions: Alcohol always causes pancreatitis - only 5-10% of heavy drinkers develop CP
Normal CT rules out chronic pancreatitis - early disease requires EUS/MRCP
Pain always worsens with disease progression - 'burnt-out' phase has less pain
